subject: Re: DCP JV Baseball Parent/Guardian Emails (Corrected)
body:
Hello again,
Sorry to send another email today! But, I wanted to update you all about our plan for tomorrow. Tomorrow morning from 6:00am - 7:00am, we will practice before school at Bradley Fieldhouse. We are hoping that the field will be playable for tomorrow's game. If it is playable, the boys will go over to Horner Park after school. If it is not playable, we will not practice or meet after school since we're going to be practicing in the morning. I will send updates if things change.
Best,
Coach Hinkamp
On Wed, Apr 2, 2025 at 11:12 AM Zachary Hinkamp <
zhinkamp@depaulprep.org
> wrote:
Hello all,
I hope you're doing well! I'm reaching out to let you know that our game today against Riverside-Brookfield at Horner Park has been canceled due to weather. We will NOT be practicing today, so the boys have the day off! We are hoping to get this game rescheduled for this Friday (location to be determined). When this is finalized, I will circle back to let you all know. Tomorrow's game is also questionable based on the amount of rain we've gotten/will get throughout the day today, so I will let you and the boys know about that tomorrow when we know more. Thank you for your flexibility and understanding!
Best,
Coach Hinkamp
On Tue, Apr 1, 2025 at 1:25 PM Zachary Hinkamp <
zhinkamp@depaulprep.org
> wrote:
My apologies for the typo in my previous email. Wednesday's game against Riverside Brookfield is also at home (Hoerner Park) at 4:30pm.
On Tue, Apr 1, 2025 at 11:03 AM Zachary Hinkamp <
zhinkamp@depaulprep.org
> wrote:
Hello all,
I'm reaching out to let you know that there is a slight change for our game at Deerfield High School this afternoon at 4:30pm. We will now be playing on their Lower Level field, located behind their Varsity field. Their Varsity field is still underwater, but the Lower Level field is playable! The Frosh/Soph game against Deerfield has been moved to another location so we can play there. Also, the bus will be leaving from DCP at 3:00pm today. My apologies for not relaying this information earlier.
Looking ahead to the remaining games on our schedule this week:
Tomorrow's game at Riverside Brookfield isn't looking great, as the weather is supposed to get a bit rough with a lot of rain. I will communicate to you and the boys when I get information about this. 
For Thursday, we play at home against Amundsen, but based on the amount of rain we get tomorrow, Hoerner might be unplayable so I will let you all know about that when I hear. 
Friday the boys will have the day off of practice. 
Finally, Saturday we have a 10:00am game at Niles North. There will not be a bus to take us to this game, so we ask that you/the boys get themselves to the field (I will let them know when to get there when we get closer to that day). Niles North is a turf field, so even with the projected rain in the forecast, I'm hoping we can still get this game in! 
Again, I will make sure to communicate with you and the boys when I get word on these games.
Best,
Coach Hinkamp
Best,
Coach Hinkamp
On Sun, Mar 30, 2025 at 2:36 PM Zachary Hinkamp <
zhinkamp@depaulprep.org
> wrote:
Hello all,
I hope you’ve had a great weekend! I’m reaching out to share this week’s game/practice schedule. It is as follows:
-Monday 3/31: Game vs Glenbrook North 4:45pm at Hoerner Park
-Tuesday 4/1: Game at Deerfield High School 4:30pm
-Wednesday 4/2: Game vs Riverside Brookfield 4:30pm at Hoerner Park
-Thursday 4/3: Game vs Amundsen 4:30pm at Hoerner Park
-Friday 4/4: Off
-Saturday 4/5: Game at Niles North High School (turf) 10:00am
I will let the boys know about bus departure times this week. Looking forward to another great week!
GO RAMS!
Coach Hinkamp

Hello all,
I hope you've all thawed out after yesterday's double header! Thank you to those that were able to come out and support us in the cold! I thought it was a great start to the season! 
This week is busy with games Monday-Thursday and then again on Saturday. This week's game/practice schedule is as follows:
-Monday 3/24: Game 6:30pm vs St. Pat's @ Reed-Dunning (Bus leaves DCP at 4:00pm)
-Tuesday 3/25: Game 4:30pm @ Whitney Young (Bus leaves DCP at 3:00pm)
-Wednesday 3/26: Game 4:30pm @ Niles West (Bus leaves DCP at 3:00pm)
-Thursday 3/27: Game 5:00pm @ U-High (Bus departure time TBD, will let boys know ASAP)
-Friday 3/28: Practice 3:00pm - 5:00pm @ Kerry Wood Field (might have to shift time and location)
-Saturday 3/29: Game 12:00pm @ Schaumburg (Bud departure time TBD, will let boys know ASAP)
I will follow up with another email when I hear back from Coach Colon regarding Thursday's bus departure, Friday's practice time and location, and Saturday's bus departure. 
GO RAMS!
Coach Hinkamp

zhinkamp@depaulprep.org
> wrote:
Hello all,
It was very nice meeting many of you last night! As promised, here is the updated email chain (hoping I've got it correct this time!). As a reminder, I will share the practice schedule for the rest of the week, as well as the week of Spring Break:
Thursday 3/13: No Practice (hoping the boys go to the basketball game)
Friday 3/14: Practice 5:30pm - 7:00pm @ Clark Park
Saturday 3/15: Practice 8:00am - 10:00am @ Kerry Wood Field
SPRING BREAK
Monday 3/17: No Practice
Tuesday 3/18: No Practice
Wednesday 3/19: No Practice
Thursday 3/20: Practice (Time/Location TBD - will communicate when confirmed)
Friday 3/21: Practice (Time/Location TBD - will communicate when confirmed)
Saturday 3/22: Games 10:00am / 12:00pm (Double Header) vs Taft @ Laramie Park (Skokie)
I will be sending another email today or tomorrow (whenever I'm able to get this information confirmed) regarding the practice times and locations for Thursday and Friday of Spring Break. 
Again, thank you all for everything you've done/will do for the boys and team this year! 
GO RAMS!
Coach Hinkamp

subject: VIP Access Summer Festival of Soccer 2026
body:
Hi 
Monica, 
Set to be hosted in 2026, with 48 Teams in attendance, the 
Summer Festival of Soccer
 is a bucket list event spanning 16 cities across the 
United States, 
Mexico
 and Canada. 
 
Returning to the United States for the first time since 1994, this is 
a great opportunity
 to treat you 
key clients to an unforgettable experience
 at the most 
anticipated
 event of the decade.
 
Visit our website for more information: 
2026 Summer Festival of Soccer
 
With 
VIP access
, including exclusive on-site hospitality, live-entertainment and chauffeur transfers, our bespoke packages are designed on the requirements of your group, with the ability to 
choose a specific match 
to attend at a city / venue of your choice.
 
Whether 
it’s
 a group-game, a knock-out stage match or the Final, please let me know your desired venue or simply 
book a 10-minute call
 so we can go over your 
group’s requirements
 and our 
exclusive packages.
 
Andrew Kokotov
Associate Director - North America
M: +1 514 726 6415 | T: +1 514 289 9700 ext: 134
About

 by marcusevans. 
Marcus Evans provides high level industry specific summits, conferences, training and online events delivering over 500 events per year. Two ski trips in one?

Hit the slopes

book soon!
Want notices on upcoming sales to Iceland and Europe?
 Have your friends and family 
sign up for our newsletter
 today, and don't forget to 
pick Nashville as your preferred gateway
 for special offers exclusive to Music City!
 
Book soon
 
The real unreal
A place that exists beyond your wildest AI prompts
As the line between what’s real and what’s fake becomes increasingly blurred, we want you to enjoy 
real photos of Iceland
 and celebrate authentic travel experiences. Iceland is a place where you can have a 
real unreal

Get real
 
Iceland Fly & Drive Vacation Package
From $689 per person, includes unlimited mileage
With the independence provided with this lcelandair holiday, the how, when and where of exploring Iceland is completely up to you, behind the wheel, with nothing but open roads ahead. 
There’s no better way to explore at your own pace than with a car rental.
 
Grab the wheel

From $1,566 per person, includes unlimited mileage

a self-driving holiday in your own motorhome - the perfect way to experience the county’s natural phenomena and incredible sights at your own pace.

subject: Specialty Plays: Virtual Workshop - Registration OPEN!
body:
View in browser
SHOP SWAG
ONLINE PROGRAMS
CAMPS & EVENTS
When the pressure is on & a perfect play at the plate is needed, will your catcher be ready?
REGISTER FOR THE VIRTUAL WORKSHOP
 
Is your catcher prepared for those rare but game-changing specialty plays?
Although they don't happen often, 
specialty plays can be the difference between winning and losing crucial games
.
Transform Your Catcher's Game in Just Two Days
Join me for a virtual workshop designed specifically to master the techniques, strategies, and safety protocols for executing specialty plays that can save innings and win games.
This clinic will help parents, coaches and catchers:
Who want to 
elevate performance
 in crucial game moments
Who need 
tools & knowledge
 to excel in specialized, high-impact plays
Who want to help their catchers perform 
confidently & safely
 in high-pressure situations
What You'll Learn:
✅ 
Effective techniques
 for executing high-pressure specialty plays
✅ How to build 
confidence and comfort
 with crucial game-changing moments
✅ 
Safety protocols
 for dangerous plays at the plate
✅ Foolproof strategies to 
catch every catchable pop-up
The Details ⬇️
April 26th & 27th (Saturday & Sunday)
5:00pm-7:30pm PST each day
Cost: $20
Are you ready to transform your game?
YES! COUNT ME IN!
 
▶️  This 2-day workshop will take place via Zoom and an email will be sent out with the replay link after the workshop concludes for the day.
🎯  If you can't make it live, don't worry... you can access the replays for free for 24 hours, or we have an option for you to access the recordings for 90 days after the workshop! Just grab the VIP option after you register for the workshop, and you'll be all set.
I'll do lectures, give demonstrations and answer any questions you have.
Have questions? Hit reply and I'll get back to you as soon as possible.
I hope to see you there!
Todd Coburn
The Catching Guy
thecatchingguy.com
Gamer Baseball LLC, PO Box 18083, Reno, NV 89511, United States

Hi Monica,
You may have seen a recent message from Sylvia Strobel, our President and CEO, 
about the threats to public media funding
. I’m writing to invite you to take the next step and 
join
 the TPT community.
We’re not chasing a quick fix. We’re working to build a stable foundation—and that starts with new supporters who step up when it matters most.
That’s why we’re asking new supporters to 
join
 as monthly sustainers—and right now, your first gifts will be 
matched dollar-for-dollar
 up to $5,000 through our TPT Member Challenge.
 
Match my Monthly Gift
 
Prefer to start with a one-time gift? That will also be matched
 and deeply appreciated.
This is a perfect moment to take action and make your support go further.
 
 
 
All the best,
David Preston
Vice President of Membership
Twin Cities PBS
 
 
P.S.
 Thanks to our $5,000 Member Challenge, your first gift will be matched—doubling the impact of the first $5,000 we raise from new donors who 
step up to support TPT
.
 
 
 
 
Watch
 
 
Schedule
 
 
Donate
 
 
Subscribe
 
Twin Cities Public Television 
172 East Fourth Street, Saint Paul, MN 55101

subject: Re: DCP JV Baseball Parent/Guardian Emails (Corrected)
body:
Hello all,
I hope you're doing well! I'm reaching out to let you know that our game today against Riverside-Brookfield at Horner Park has been canceled due to weather. We will NOT be practicing today, so the boys have the day off! We are hoping to get this game rescheduled for this Friday (location to be determined). When this is finalized, I will circle back to let you all know. Tomorrow's game is also questionable based on the amount of rain we've gotten/will get throughout the day today, so I will let you and the boys know about that tomorrow when we know more. Thank you for your flexibility and understanding!
Best,
Coach Hinkamp
On Tue, Apr 1, 2025 at 1:25 PM Zachary Hinkamp <
zhinkamp@depaulprep.org
> wrote:
My apologies for the typo in my previous email. Wednesday's game against Riverside Brookfield is also at home (Hoerner Park) at 4:30pm.
On Tue, Apr 1, 2025 at 11:03 AM Zachary Hinkamp <
zhinkamp@depaulprep.org
> wrote:
Hello all,
I'm reaching out to let you know that there is a slight change for our game at Deerfield High School this afternoon at 4:30pm. We will now be playing on their Lower Level field, located behind their Varsity field. Their Varsity field is still underwater, but the Lower Level field is playable! The Frosh/Soph game against Deerfield has been moved to another location so we can play there. Also, the bus will be leaving from DCP at 3:00pm today. My apologies for not relaying this information earlier.
Looking ahead to the remaining games on our schedule this week:
Tomorrow's game at Riverside Brookfield isn't looking great, as the weather is supposed to get a bit rough with a lot of rain. I will communicate to you and the boys when I get information about this. 
For Thursday, we play at home against Amundsen, but based on the amount of rain we get tomorrow, Hoerner might be unplayable so I will let you all know about that when I hear. 
Friday the boys will have the day off of practice. 
Finally, Saturday we have a 10:00am game at Niles North. There will not be a bus to take us to this game, so we ask that you/the boys get themselves to the field (I will let them know when to get there when we get closer to that day). Niles North is a turf field, so even with the projected rain in the forecast, I'm hoping we can still get this game in! 
Again, I will make sure to communicate with you and the boys when I get word on these games.
Best,
Coach Hinkamp
Best,
Coach Hinkamp
On Sun, Mar 30, 2025 at 2:36 PM Zachary Hinkamp <
zhinkamp@depaulprep.org
> wrote:
Hello all,
I hope you’ve had a great weekend! I’m reaching out to share this week’s game/practice schedule. It is as follows:
-Monday 3/31: Game vs Glenbrook North 4:45pm at Hoerner Park
-Tuesday 4/1: Game at Deerfield High School 4:30pm
-Wednesday 4/2: Game vs Riverside Brookfield 4:30pm at Hoerner Park
-Thursday 4/3: Game vs Amundsen 4:30pm at Hoerner Park
-Friday 4/4: Off
-Saturday 4/5: Game at Niles North High School (turf) 10:00am
I will let the boys know about bus departure times this week. Looking forward to another great week!
GO RAMS!
Coach Hinkamp

On Sun, Mar 23, 2025 at 12:47 PM Zachary Hinkamp <
zhinkamp@depaulprep.org
> wrote:
Hello all,
I hope you've all thawed out after yesterday's double header! Thank you to those that were able to come out and support us in the cold! I thought it was a great start to the season! 
This week is busy with games Monday-Thursday and then again on Saturday. This week's game/practice schedule is as follows:
-Monday 3/24: Game 6:30pm vs St. Pat's @ Reed-Dunning (Bus leaves DCP at 4:00pm)
-Tuesday 3/25: Game 4:30pm @ Whitney Young (Bus leaves DCP at 3:00pm)
-Wednesday 3/26: Game 4:30pm @ Niles West (Bus leaves DCP at 3:00pm)
-Thursday 3/27: Game 5:00pm @ U-High (Bus departure time TBD, will let boys know ASAP)
-Friday 3/28: Practice 3:00pm - 5:00pm @ Kerry Wood Field (might have to shift time and location)
-Saturday 3/29: Game 12:00pm @ Schaumburg (Bud departure time TBD, will let boys know ASAP)
I will follow up with another email when I hear back from Coach Colon regarding Thursday's bus departure, Friday's practice time and location, and Saturday's bus departure. 
GO RAMS!
Coach Hinkamp
On Thu, Mar 13, 2025 at 7:03 AM Zachary Hinkamp <
zhinkamp@depaulprep.org
> wrote:
Hello all,
It was very nice meeting many of you last night! As promised, here is the updated email chain (hoping I've got it correct this time!). As a reminder, I will share the practice schedule for the rest of the week, as well as the week of Spring Break:
Thursday 3/13: No Practice (hoping the boys go to the basketball game)
Friday 3/14: Practice 5:30pm - 7:00pm @ Clark Park
Saturday 3/15: Practice 8:00am - 10:00am @ Kerry Wood Field
SPRING BREAK
Monday 3/17: No Practice
Tuesday 3/18: No Practice
Wednesday 3/19: No Practice
Thursday 3/20: Practice (Time/Location TBD - will communicate when confirmed)
Friday 3/21: Practice (Time/Location TBD - will communicate when confirmed)
Saturday 3/22: Games 10:00am / 12:00pm (Double Header) vs Taft @ Laramie Park (Skokie)
I will be sending another email today or tomorrow (whenever I'm able to get this information confirmed) regarding the practice times and locations for Thursday and Friday of Spring Break. 
Again, thank you all for everything you've done/will do for the boys and team this year! 
GO RAMS!
Coach Hinkamp

subject: 💡 Igniting Brilliance: Female Trailblazers in the Communications World!
body:
Your Weekly NYWICI Newsletter!
 
 
About
 
Membership
 
 
Leading with Style: A Fireside Chat with Rebecca Minkoff
﻿
Mark your calendars for 
April 22, 2025, 
from 
12:00 – 1:00 PM EST
 for an exclusive conversation with and Real Housewife of New York, 
Rebecca Minkoff
 as she shares insights from her book "
Fearless: The New Rules for Unlocking Creativity, Courage, and Success
."
In this session, Rebecca will share her inspiring journey from industry outsider to creator of a global brand. She’ll open up about the bold, unconventional strategies that led to her success, including transforming self-doubt into confidence, overcoming setbacks, and cultivating a powerful, authentic network.
This fireside chat will be filled with valuable insights, actionable advice, and Rebecca’s candid wisdom on how to unlock creativity, courage, and success. Plus, you'll have the chance to ask her your own questions during the live Q&A.
Location
: Virtual (Zoom link provided upon registration)
Cost
: Free for NYWICI members | $20 for non-members
Spots are limited—register now to hear from one of fashion’s most fearless leaders!
register here
 
 
 
NYWICI 2025 Matrix Awards: Honoring Industry Luminaries - Registration Now Open
Join us on
 May 20, 2025
, at the Ziegfeld Ballroom in NYC for the 
2025 Matrix Awards
, where we will honor women who are breaking barriers and shaping the future of our industry.
This year’s theme, Leading Luminaries, highlights those who inspire by example, lead with purpose, and make a lasting impact. These trailblazing women exhibit resilience, perseverance, and dedication, paving the way for others to follow. They don’t just achieve—they empower, transform, and leave a legacy for future generations.
Don’t miss this chance to celebrate the powerful women who are lighting the way forward. Register now for an evening of recognition, inspiration, and celebration of their exceptional leadership and influence.
register here
 
 
 
Member Spotlight: Joanna Ruiz!
Meet
 Joanna Ruiz
, an innovative leader in advertising and communications, now serving as the President of Havas Links! With a passion for storytelling and a background in MarTech, data analytics, and operations, Joanna is transforming healthcare communications through creative, data-driven strategies.
From crafting jingles as a child to launching impactful campaigns on women’s heart health and healthcare bias, Joanna’s journey is a testament to the power of storytelling in driving change. She’s also a fierce advocate for diversity in leadership, encouraging women to be bold, confident, and persistent in their careers.
Read more about her inspiring journey!
read more here
 
 
 
Join the New NYWICI LinkedIn Group!
Exciting news! NYWICI has launched a new 
Member LinkedIn Group
—a dedicated space for communications professionals to connect, share insights, and support one another. Whether you're looking for career advice, networking opportunities, or industry discussions, this group is the perfect place to engage with like-minded professionals.
Join the conversation today and be part of a thriving community and fellow NYWICI members!
join here
 
 
 
Listen to this WomenHeard Podcast Episode with Pilar Guzmán
In this episode, WomenHeard host Julie Hochheiser Ilkovich interviews Pilar Guzmán, Editorial Director at Oprah Daily – the eponymous media and membership community from Hearst Magazines and Oprah Winfrey! Pilar oversees content strategy across the brand’s platforms.
Listen to this episode for the career advice that solidified Pilar’s path in creative endeavors. Plus, how she elevated awareness for women’s health issues by crowdsourcing wisdom from new mothers.
listen here
 
 
 
Explore NYWICI’s Latest Blogs
The Three Cs: Candor, Change, and Community with Leslie Jane Seymour
 In the latest episode of NYWICI’s WomenHeard: Changemakers podcast, host Georgia Galanoudis sits down with Lesley Jane Seymour, former editor-in-chief of Marie Claire and founder of CoveyClub.com. Lesley shares candid insights on leadership, embracing change, and the power of community.
CANDOR 
– Lesley’s leadership philosophy? Hands-off, empowering, and built on trust. She believes work should be a place for learning and growth, not just routine tasks.
CHANGE 
– Now in New Orleans, Lesley is embracing the unknown with excitement. Her advice? Take the leap—even if you don’t know where it leads.
COMMUNITY 
– Whether growing your circle or deepening existing connections, Lesley highlights the importance of support, especially in today’s world. And NYWICI is here to help!

subject: Must Read! How to Sell to the Government
body:
How to Sell to the Government                                                                       
Must Read! How to Sell to the Government
Learn More >>>
How to Sell to the Government
Selling to the Federal Government seems daunting and for most people, knowing where to be is a massive challenge. Once you get in and develop a marketing plan, piece by piece things start to come together and the federal government then becomes like working with any large corporation.
The reality is that people want to do business with people they know. Federal employees must follow FAR (Federal Acquisitions Regulations) in their purchasing however they also need confidence that the services they are acquiring will meet their mission goals. This gives federal employees the ability to weigh past performance enough to go with firms they have a track record with.
Step 1 – Getting Ready and Prospecting for Federal Business
Building Lists of Key Decision Makers
There are sources such as sam.gov where you can look at awarded contracts and back into the contracting officers that awarded those contracts. This is a good way to build relationships and increase their confidence that you will be able to perform future work for their agency. Additionally, these contractors will sometimes have smaller projects they can award to you to “try you out”. Only a small percentage of available contracts are posted on sam.gov, often sam.gov as a procurement avenue is reserved for needs that the federal government does not already have a vendor in mind for the procurement.
SBA Certifications
SBA Certifications also can help you by gaining introductions through letters of introduction by SBA Business Development Specialists. Federal procurement officers are more likely to respond to other federal employees than to outside businesses seeking to solicit them. Through meetings obtained in this manner often a procurement officer will tell you about the potential for a sole source or direct award contract or a set-aside contract that applies to your specific certification.
Subcontracting
Many firms start with subcontracting before they become prime contractors. Generally, this is advisable to all SBA certification holders except for 8(a) firms who should focus on prime contracts because 8(a) firms are only permitted to be in the 8(a) program for 9 years while the other certifications can be maintained and therefore are evergreen.
Once a firm makes contacts within an agency, they can then network within that agency, learn the lingo, and unique needs of that agency, and better position themselves for making the jump into federal contracting.
GSA Schedules
A GSA Schedule can be an effective way of breaking into the federal government. There are some business requirements such as years in business and being able to provide several references to obtain a contract. The GSA pre-vets your firm and this adds confidence to federal buyers, it also adds visibility, and the ability to bid on contracts only GSA contract holders can bid on through GSA-eBuy. A GSA Schedule also provides your firm with a government-wide contract so when you find an interested federal buyer you don’t get the “I would love to buy from you but... I have no FAR compliant way of doing so…”
Sam.gov formerly Fbo.gov
Every day firms find procurements that are a good match for their firm through sam.gov. Monitoring sam.gov for opportunities for your firm to bid on should be an important part of any federal sales break-in strategy.
Step 2 – Target your Agencies
Your firm needs to begin by getting the targets down to approximately three agencies. From there once you begin getting to know those agencies ideally you get it down to one. Your geographical service area and capabilities should match the needs of this agency. By focusing on this one agency, you will learn who the key decision makers are for your goods and services, what things matter most to an agency to tailor your offerings as well as key terminology and what role you can play in carving out a niche for your firm.
﻿
Step 3 – Take Advantage of Your Opportunity
Federal Contact Performance Evaluation
Being vigilant in your communication with contracting officers about your performance on a contract is critical to achieving an “excellent” performance evaluation. Below is a scale as to how your performance will be graded by federal agencies. A “good” performance evaluation is the minimum level a firm should achieve if it hopes to continue working with the government. “Excellent” is how you build your business.
From conversations we have had with contracting officers, all things being equal a firm with an “excellent” rating can charge as much as 7% more and still be awarded the contract over a firm with a “good” rating. Therefore, know that the extra effort you put in today to ensure the “excellent” rating will come back as increased profits down the road.
Step 4 – Leveraging Your Past Performance
Now it is time to grow your firm into other areas. It is time to focus on GWACs (Government-wide Acquisition Contracts), IDIQs (Indefinite Delivery Indefinite Quantity Contracts), and BPAs (Blanket Purchase Agreements). These contracting vehicles gain your firm access to large buckets of money and a finite number of vendors. These contracts also help your firm to break into other federal agencies that will order from these contracting vehicles and grow your business. 
Firms with SBA Certification at this point should be moving from Sole Source Contracts to Set-aside Contracts. Sole Source Contacts are indeed non-competitive; however, Set-aside contracts are generally much larger and still have modest competition. So, firms that are trying to increase their sales will make this shift.
If your firm can execute this marketing plan you should be able to become a large federal contractor in approximately 4 years.
Emily Hatchel

www.fedvital.com

subject: Points to Boost Your Company's WOSB Federal Sales!
body:
Points to Boost Your Company's WOSB Federal Sales                                                   
Points to Boost Your Company's WOSB Federal Sales!
Learn More >>>
Points to Boost Your Company's WOSB Federal Sales
Point 1: WOSB Certification as a Federal Contract Advantage
Obtaining certification as a Woman Owned Small Business (WOSB) speaks of significant advantages to small businesses seeking government contracts. It facilitates woman-owned businesses' acquisition of their first government contract and helps them maintain their business relationships with federal agencies.
Point 2: Impressive 2024 WOSB Statistics
In 2024, around 14,606 WOSB firms worked with the federal government, making a combined $27.6 billion in sales. On average, each of these firms got about $2.2 million in federal contracts. These numbers show the real value of having WOSB certification, proving it's a smart move for woman-owned small businesses.
Point 3: Enhancing Sales through GSA Schedule Contracts
Obtaining a GSA Schedule Contract will enable WOSB businesses to increase sales even further. Direct sales from GSA Schedules to 3,663 WOSB companies totaled $8.3 billion in 2024. That works up to roughly $2.3 million in sales for each company. Thus, WOSB companies can boost their government sales and fortify their market position by utilizing a GSA Schedule, which is an effective strategy.
Point 4: Seven Advantages of GSA Schedule for WOSB Firms
Contracting Vehicle:
 Provides a FAR-compliant method for federal buyers to make purchases, addressing a common struggle for small businesses.
Market Research Visibility:
 Increases visibility through GSA Advantage, the preferred site for federal buyers' market research.
Access to GSA e-buy:
 Offers a specialized bulletin board for solicitation, facilitating initial sales to target agencies and subsequent opportunities.
Gateway to GWACs:
 Positions WOSB firms to enter Governmentwide Acquisition Contracts, reducing administrative burdens and demonstrating competency.
Subcontracting Opportunities:
 Expand opportunities as prime contractors using a GSA Schedule are not subject to audit, saving compliance efforts.
Flexibility with Products and Services:
 Enables quick addition of new products and services to the repertoire through GSA MAS Contract modifications.
Non-Schedule Items Inclusion:
 Permits the addition of non-schedule items for completing contracts, provided over fifty percent are purchased from the firm's GSA Schedule.
Combining WOSB Certification with a GSA Schedule is a smart strategy for woman-owned small businesses in federal contracting. The 2024 statistics and the advantages of the GSA Schedule clearly show that this approach not only helps in getting initial contracts but also sets the stage for ongoing growth and success in the federal market. It's strongly recommended for eligible businesses to go for both certifications, leading to a significant threefold increase in sales opportunities.
Give us a call for an in-depth discussion and get you started now.
Emily Hatchel

For Sellers:

Seasonal Recipe: Asparagus Gruyere Tart
 
Looking for a simply fabulous spring appetizer to serve at your Easter brunch? This month’s featured dish, when made with plump, in-season asparagus, makes for a sophisticated, visually pleasing appetizer. Store-bought puff pastry is a great shortcut, and Fontina cheese can be substituted for Gruyere.

subject: U. S. Senate Information Technology Support Contract (ITSC) V
body:
U. S. Senate Information Technology Support Contract (ITSC) V 
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
GovBidWriters LLC
, a premier proposal writing firm in the Washington, D.C., metro area, specializes in helping businesses navigate federal contracting opportunities. 
Description: 
The United States Senate (“Senate”) Office of the Sergeant at Arms (“SAA”) is responsible for managing the Information Technology Support Contract (“ITSC”) for the outsourcing of essential IT services in support of the IT Support Program. The IT Support Program will provide support services for workstation and server hardware, operating system software, and application software as well as help desk services, break-fix and maintenance services, and on-site maintenance and support for the Senate in Washington, DC, and the fifty (50) states for Senate Member, Committee, Leadership and Officer Offices.
Hardware acquisition, maintenance and support includes, but is not limited to, workstations, laptops, file servers, scanners, printers, videoconferencing, televisions, flat panel monitors and smart boards, and wireless mobile technology (devices, platforms, and WANs). Software support includes, but is not limited to operating systems, communication packages, and commercial software applications. Support includes the staffing of a hotline/help desk and providing for other support functions. All requirements herein are mandatory unless otherwise noted.
Contract Value: 
$166,000,000
NAIC: 
541990
Due Date:
 4/25/25, 12:00 PM
Duration:
 2 year(s) base plus 4 x 1 year(s) option(s)
​
​

subject: Delivered: Your Amazon.com order #111-7373053-8790616
How to blend meritocracy and DEI
body:
April 1st foolery; new EEOC guidance; the impact on veterans; Morgan Stanley DEI backfires  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
View in browser
 
 April 01, 2025
In a shocking reversal, the White House today announced that it is restarting DEI initiatives across all government agencies, restoring funding to all universities, and offering tax breaks to any corporation that shows tangible progress on DEI. 
April Fools'!
 … unfortunately 😭 
 
All jokes aside, we are excited to introduce the 
MIME
 framework, which aligns the calls for meritocracy with key DEI objectives—see below.
 
– Team Aleria 
DEI Backlash: 
Pros
 and 
Cons
Stories focused on the anti-DEI backlash, and efforts to put a stop to the nonsense!
 
Quantifying DEI
Exploring the tangible aspects of DEI and current efforts to quantify it
 
DEI Resources
Useful tools and information to support your DEI efforts
 
The Complexity of DEI
Unintended consequences and ripple effects of DEI
 
Golden Nuggets,
 Silver Linings
Unexpected bits of good news... when we can find them.
We almost never share links to podcasts, but this episode of 
The Future of Work
 is awesome: Jill Finlayson speaks with Bo Young Lee, who brings a wealth of experience to discuss some of the hottest topics about the DEI backlash. On the academic front, 
Harvard will offer free tuition
 to families making less than $200K/year—joining a few other elite schools in diversity push. And our unique work keeps attracting attention: check out the 
latest podcast
 and some quotes in 
CSO magazine
.
 
 
Aleria Happenings
The latest from the Aleria Team
 
Introducing 
MIME
: the Measurable approach to Meritocracy for 
ALL
 Employees
Organizations are searching for ways to comply with the administration's executive orders and the call to “restore meritocracy." But how do you create a truly merit-based system that benefits
 all
 employees? Aleria's 
Measuring Inclusion and Merit for Efficiency
 (
MIME
) 
framework provides the answer.
 
Anchored in the 
MIME
 framework, our 
Inclusive Leadership
 and 
Inclusive Management Training
 
programs give your teams the knowledge, data, tools, and best practices to foster a high-performing, stable workforce—without guesswork, backlash, or legal exposure. 
Our training is fully customizable, from half-day sessions to multi-day deep dives, both in-person and virtually. 
With 
MIME
, you don't just talk about meritocracy—you implement it effectively in a way that benefits 
all
 employees!
 
 
Visit our website
 for additional information, 
send us an email
 to learn more, or use the button below to schedule a call with Aleria's Founder and Chief Scientist, Paolo Gaudiano, who can provide 
more details and answer any questions about how 
Measuring Inclusion and Merit for Efficiency
 can give your organization a competitive advantage.
Book a call with Paolo
 
Mark Your Calendars
DEI-related events, applications and opportunities. Submit relevant events to 
info@aleria.tech
On April 3, 2025 at 12pm US/ET, join Charter and Understood for 
Neurodiversity and the Future of Business
, a discussion of the workplace designs, team dynamics, and leadership approaches to maximize the strengths of neurodivergent workers. The presentation includes case studies and resources that you can use in your own organization. 
Free registration
.
On April 3-9, 2025, join the 17th 
Annual ReelAbilities Film Festival: New York
. This amazing festival, which spans multiple venues and virtual showings, reframes disability and celebrates inclusion and accessibility through film. 
Get your tickets today
!
On April 9, 2025 at 12pm US/ET, join a Fairgodboss webinar on 
Allyship and Self-Advocacy for Career Growth
, featuring leaders from Cargill, who will discuss self-advocacy and allyship. Gain practical strategies to communicate effectively, boost confidence, challenge workplace biases, and foster an inclusive environment for career growth and support. 
Free registration

On April 10 at 11:00 am US/ET join our Chief Scientist Paolo Gaudiano for a FREE webinar on 
Rethinking DEI: Addressing Common Misconceptions. 
Paolo we'll dive into the misconceptions surrounding diversity and inclusion, address concerns about meritocracy, and explore practical ways to approach DEI while staying compliant with current policies.

subject: $750M - Air Force CENTCOM has been Extended
body:
$750M - Air Force CENTCOM has been Extended 
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
GovBidWriters LLC
, a premier proposal writing firm in the Washington, D.C., metro area, specializes in helping businesses navigate federal contracting opportunities. 
CENTCOM's closing date has been extended until Q&As and RFP documents are solidified.  At which time, the updated RFP amendments and Q&A responses will be posted along with a final RFP due date. This is your last chance to secure your spot to bid.
SOLICITATION DESCRIPTION:
 The 
Department of the Air Force's Air Mobility Command
 is seeking to acquire professional services for CENTCOM Headquarters through an Indefinite Delivery Indefinite Quantity (IDIQ) contract. The solicitation requires contractors to provide 
a comprehensive range of professional services including management activities involving policy, doctrine, planning, intelligence, strategy, exercises, logistics, assessments, and operations for multiple USCENTCOM directorates and DoD counterparts
. 
Key contract requirements include maintaining a TOP SECRET facility clearance, providing personnel with minimum SECRET clearances
, and supporting work at 
MacDill AFB in Tampa, Florida
, as well as potential CONUS and OCONUS locations. The evaluation will use a best value tradeoff approach where past performance is significantly more important than price, with technical proposals rated as acceptable or unacceptable. 
The contract is a 100% small business set-aside specifically for 
Service-Disabled Veteran Owned Small Business (SDVOSB) and SBA certified 8(a) small businesses
, with plans to award 10 contracts in each socioeconomic pool
.
 The total contract ceiling is $750 million, with a period of performance including a one-year base period plus four one-year options and a six-month extension option
. The contract will support approximately 30-35 trips annually, totaling around 700 travel days, with a travel budget of $400,000 per full year. Contractors must be prepared to propose on 75% of task order requests within a 12-month period, with task orders potentially ranging from $2,500 to $200 million. Contractors will perform work primarily at HQ USCENTCOM in Tampa, FL 33621, with the ordering period spanning from August 1, 2025, through January 31, 2031, and a mandatory virtual post-award orientation featuring a $150 minimum guarantee for awardees.
Solicitation
:
 
https://sam.gov/opp/c4e069c3cdf94ea184e8ae867878cd79/view
Evaluation Factors
The following evaluation factors and subfactors will be used to evaluate each proposal. 
Factor 1: Technical Subfactor 
1.1: Staffing Approach Subfactor 
1.2: Management Approach 
Factor 2: Past Performance 
Factor 3: Price 2.2 In accordance with FAR 15.304(e), past performance is significantly more important than price. (Note: Technical will be rated on an acceptable/unacceptable basis. To be eligible for award, an offeror shall be acceptable in all Technical subfactors.)
www.GovBidWriters.com

subject: What’s Cooking at the Galilee Culinary Institute by JNF
body:
Spring is in the Air
Discover the latest from GCI: heartfelt progress, Israeli trends, and recipes to savor
 
 
GCI Bulletin   |  Spring 2025
 
Spring Is In The Air And With It Endless Possibilities
A heartfelt journey through resilience, culinary innovation, and the vibrant stories shaping Israel's future—discover the flavors, trends, and community-driven efforts that define the Galilee Culinary Institute's mission to build a brighter tomorrow.
Latest Stories
 
Message from Co-Founder
Lior Lev Sercarz 
As co-founder and chief culinary officer of the Galilee Culinary Institute by Jewish National Fund-USA (GCI by JNF), I’ve written and spoken about why I believe this initiative will be a game-changer for the region. But at its heart, our vision is simple: bringing life to the Upper Eastern Galilee in Israel’s north.
Read More
 
 
Meet our new operations manager, Amit Avishai.
Amit Avishai does not understand why anyone would choose to live anywhere in Israel other than in the Galilee. “Life here is amazing,” he said. We have everything: beautiful landscapes, welcoming people, vibrant cultures—you name it. I can’t imagine wanting to live somewhere else.”
Read More
 
 
Update on the campus
Serving meals, smiles, and love to 8,000 soldiers daily.
Watch Here 
 
What does Texas have to do with GCI by JNF?
Lior Lev Sercarz knew he had to find the perfect grill for GCI’s restaurant. “Grilling is a national pastime in Israel,” he said. “People even have grills in the trunks of their cars because ‘ya never know when you might want to stop off and grill.’” 
Read More
 
 
Wait for it... what’s coming around the bend? 
While the world waits for GCI by JNF to open, a whirlwind of activity is happening. Before the first year’s cohort shows up on campus, expansion projects designed to create revenue streams, enhance professional training opportunities, address industry workforce shortages, and position the culinary center as a leading institution in Israel’s food and hospitality sector are already on the drawing board.
Read More
 
Our recipes just in time for Passover 
 
Halva Macaroons ('Halvaroons')
 
 
Matzo Brei
  
Looking forward to all this and more.
Want to reach us? Email 
amit@gcibyjnf.com
 with your comments and questions.
 
Global Conference for Israel 
Can you believe that our Global Conference for Israel, taking place in Hollywood, Florida, October 23-26, is expected to sell out months in advance? With 1,597 proud Zionists already registered, don’t miss out on this extraordinary gathering of solidarity, purpose, and impact for our land and people of Israel.
You’ll laugh, cry, and leave inspired, ready to make our light shine brighter than ever for our land and people of Israel.
Register at 
jnf.org/global
 
 
Other Happenings at
Jewish National Fund-USA 
Wow! We’re expecting over 800 homes and congregations from across the country to either host a Shabbat for Israel Friday night dinner on May 2, 2025, coinciding with Yom Ha’atzmaut—Israel’s Independence Day.
It’s not too late! Register at 
jnf.org/shabbatforisrael
 and host a Shabbat dinner for your family and friends in your home in celebration of our homeland.
Read More
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Want to help us out, donate 
here
. Thank you for supporting the GCI by JNF!
To learn more about JNF-USA, click 
here

subject: What tariffs could mean for your budget
body:
Plus, concerts to put on your calendar this month. Here’s what you need to know today.
 
.
To view this email as a web page, click 
here.
Tuesday - April 1, 2025
Today's 
Rundown
 is brought to you by WBEZ members and
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
by Bianca Cseke
 
 
 
 
 
 
Good afternoon! It’s Tuesday and the first day of April, which means 
tulips
 will soon start blooming in the Chicago area. Here’s what you need to know today.
  
1.
Trump’s promised ‘Liberation Day’ of tariffs is coming. Here’s what it could mean for you.
 
President Donald Trump says tomorrow will be “Liberation Day” — a moment when he plans to roll out a set of tariffs that he promises will free the United States from foreign goods. It is also possible the tariffs are short-lived if Trump feels he can cut a deal after imposing them.
At stake are family budgets, America’s prominence as the world’s leading financial power and the structure of the global economy, The Associated Press reports.
Most economists say the tariffs would get passed along to consumers in the form of higher prices for automobiles, groceries, housing and other goods. Corporate profits could be lower and growth more sluggish. Trump maintains more companies would open factories to avoid the taxes, though that process could take three years or more.
Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent has suggested tariffs would be a one-time price adjustment, rather than the start of an inflationary spiral. But Bessent’s conclusion rests on tariffs being brief or contained, rather than leading other countries to retaliate with their own tariffs or bleeding into other sectors of the economy such as services. [
AP
]
2.
CTU bargainers approved a tentative contract deal. Here’s what you need to know.
 
A key Chicago Teachers Union committee spent hours yesterday going through a hefty package of proposals before finally approving a tentative agreement with Chicago Public Schools. It’s a significant step toward finalizing a deal on a new four-year contract, my colleagues Sarah Karp and Nader Issa report.
CTU members will get 4% raises in the first year, then up to 5% in the next three. CPS also gave elementary school teachers an additional 10 minutes of planning time per day.
The proposed settlement cleared the hurdle of the union’s “big bargaining team,” a group of 65 educators that has negotiated with the school district for almost a year. The CTU’s 730-member House of Delegates meets tomorrow, with a ratification vote by all 30,000 members expected in the next week or two.
Once CTU members ratify the contract, the school board will have to approve it. Because the previous contract expired last June, the board also will have to amend its current budget to provide retroactive pay increases. A vote on that budget amendment and the unsuccessful efforts by the mayor’s office to convince CPS to make a city pension payment that covers CPS workers have been a major source of conflict at the board. [
WBEZ/Chicago Sun-Times
]
SPONSOR MESSAGE FROM MEEZ MEALS
Top Meal Kit Brand Right in Your Backyard
Ingredients arrive chopped and prepped
 (no dicing onions/peeling carrots). From unboxing to sizzling skillet to dinner table in 30 minutes!
Meez has 
no subscriptions
 or auto-deliveries. A 
small business
 supporting local ingredient suppliers and hand-packing each meal in their Evanston kitchen.
Visit 
meezmeals.com
, use code 
RADIO
 for 50% off first order!
3.
Cook County’s chief judge has taken over electronic monitoring for Cook County, but questions remain about staffing
 
Beginning today, anyone placed on electronic monitoring after being found a flight risk or a danger to the public will be overseen by the Adult Probation Department, administered by Cook County Chief Judge Timothy Evans.
The sheriff’s office, which has complained it can no longer safely administer the program, will continue handling its current monitor caseload, Sophie Sherry reports for the Chicago Sun-Times.
The chief judge’s office plans to hire additional probation officers in phases, with the hope of being fully staffed by next spring, according to Adult Probation Department officials who spoke before Cook County commissioners in March.
The county’s 2025 budget includes $6.3 million in funding for the Adult Probation Department, but Evans’ office told commissioners it will need closer to $10 million to make the necessary hires for this year. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
4.
Northwestern faces another congressional investigation
 
This time, the Committee on Education and the Workforce argues legal clinics at the law school are using tax dollars to “engage in progressive-left political advocacy,” Patrick Smith reports for WBEZ.
The committee, which last year called Northwestern President Michael Schill and other university presidents to testify about antisemitism on campus, is asking for the budgets and funders for all of the school’s 20-plus legal clinics. It’s also asking for the personnel file of professor Sheila Bedi, director of Northwestern’s Community Justice and Civil Rights Clinic, which works on “redressing over-policing and mass imprisonment.”
Georgetown University Law professor Deborah Epstein told WBEZ she believes the letter will, on its own, have an immediate negative impact on legal advocacy throughout the country. [
WBEZ
]
5.
10 concerts that showcase the best of Chicago’s small and midsize club scene
 
Besides the new buds popping up in gardens and parks throughout the Chicago area, another sign of spring is an active music calendar. 
WBEZ music contributor Mark Guarino compiled a list of shows to see this month.
This Friday, Canadian-born producer, songwriter and musician Daniel Lanois, who has worked on albums as enduring as U2’s 
The Joshua Tree
 and Peter Gabriel’s 
So
, takes the stage at the Epiphany Center for the Arts.
Later this month, bluegrass songwriter and mandolinist Sierra Hull plays at Thalia Hall in support of her latest record, 
A Tip Toe High Wire
.
You can see the full list in the link. [
WBEZ
]
 
Here's what else is happening
 
The White House said it’s “case closed” on the Signal group chat review. [
NPR
]
Prosecutors have been directed to seek the death penalty against UnitedHealthcare CEO killing suspect Luigi Mangione. [
AP
]
NASCAR Chicago Street Race announced upcoming closures for its July 5–6 event. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
Chicago Public Media announced leadership changes atop the Sun-Times and WBEZ. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
 
Oh, and one more thing...
 
Jamie Gustafson draws dinosaurs, sharks and pretty much anything else from the natural world. 
Some of his clients have included National Geographic, DK Smithsonian and scientists at Chicago’s Field Museum, my colleague Stefano Esposito reports for the Chicago Sun-Times.
Gustafson said he makes artistic choices based on science.
“When I take too many liberties, you get the paleontology police after you,” he said. “My least favorite thing is when someone ... says, ‘That’s not what it looked like.’ ” [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
 
Tell me something good
 
What’s the best book you’ve read recently? I finally have some room on my library hold list, and I always feel like staying in for weeks after getting back from long trips.
Sam writes:
“I just finished reading John Green’s newest book, 
Everything is Tuberculosis
. It’s a sobering tale of how TB still kills over a million people worldwide every year, but it also has uplifting stories of things that are being done globally to improve access to diagnostic tools and treatments. Highly recommended!”
Jerry writes:
“﻿I love historical fiction, but I was skeptical that a book about an orphan in Venice during the early 18th century who learns to play the violin would hold my attention. I’m not particularly partial to classical music, but I was intrigued when I learned the teacher was Vivaldi, famous for 
The Four Seasons
 symphony, and the orphan was an abandoned baby girl left at a famous institution in Venice managed by nuns. That said, 
The Instrumentalist
 by Harriet Constable, is one of the best books I’ve read this year. I was engaged from the start and the story has layers of interesting characters and social commentary. Good read even if historical fiction is not your first choice.”
Sue writes:
“I really enjoyed 
The Husbands
, by Holly Gramazio. I hate saying too much because I wouldn't want to spoil it. It really made me think and laugh and was so unexpected. CPL has it!”
Feel free to email me, and your response may be included in the newsletter this week.
Thanks for reading and have a nice night! I'll see you tomorrow.
— Bianca Cseke

body:
My apologies for the typo in my previous email. Wednesday's game against Riverside Brookfield is also at home (Hoerner Park) at 4:30pm.
On Tue, Apr 1, 2025 at 11:03 AM Zachary Hinkamp <
zhinkamp@depaulprep.org
> wrote:
Hello all,
I'm reaching out to let you know that there is a slight change for our game at Deerfield High School this afternoon at 4:30pm. We will now be playing on their Lower Level field, located behind their Varsity field. Their Varsity field is still underwater, but the Lower Level field is playable! The Frosh/Soph game against Deerfield has been moved to another location so we can play there. Also, the bus will be leaving from DCP at 3:00pm today. My apologies for not relaying this information earlier.
Looking ahead to the remaining games on our schedule this week:
Tomorrow's game at Riverside Brookfield isn't looking great, as the weather is supposed to get a bit rough with a lot of rain. I will communicate to you and the boys when I get information about this. 
For Thursday, we play at home against Amundsen, but based on the amount of rain we get tomorrow, Hoerner might be unplayable so I will let you all know about that when I hear. 
Friday the boys will have the day off of practice. 
Finally, Saturday we have a 10:00am game at Niles North. There will not be a bus to take us to this game, so we ask that you/the boys get themselves to the field (I will let them know when to get there when we get closer to that day). Niles North is a turf field, so even with the projected rain in the forecast, I'm hoping we can still get this game in! 
Again, I will make sure to communicate with you and the boys when I get word on these games.
Best,
Coach Hinkamp

subject: Meet The World’s Self-Made Billionaires
body:
Plus: Wall Street Bonuses Surge | The New Ivies Employers Love To Hire From | Federal Workers Hit The Job Market
BECOME A MEMBER
 • 
Newsletters
 • 
MyForbes
Happy Billionaires Day! It’s a busy one here at 
Forbes,
 as we just released our annual list of the world’s billionaires, highlighting the richest––and arguably most powerful––people and families across the globe. 
In total, 
Forbes 
tracked and documented the wealth of more than 
3,000 people worth a collective $16.1 trillion
. The average fortune on the list now stands at $5.3 billion, a $200 million increase from 2024. 
While many of the world’s billionaires inherited their wealth, nearly 70% of the newest names on this year’s list are 
self-made
, meaning they founded or cofounded the company that made them their billions. The newcomers include 73-year-old Sulaiman Al Habib, founder and chairman of Saudi Arabia hospital group HMG, as well as Scale AI cofounder and CEO Alexandr Wang, the list’s youngest self-made billionaire at just 28 years old.
Wang is one of just 21 individuals this year to reach billionaire status 
under the age of 30
. Of those, only Wang and 29-year-old Ed Craven are self-made, with Craven being the cofounder of Stake.com, thought to be the world’s biggest crypto-backed online casino.
So what’s the secret to their riches? For newcomer billionaire Steve Ells, it was 
Chipotle’s compensation plan.
 Though Ells sold most of his stock throughout his time as CEO and then chairman of the board at the fast-casual chain, the company’s compensation plan continued to award him Chipotle stock as it kept rising. 
And while it was the ultimate sale of 
fried chicken chain Zaxby
 that netted its cofounders their billions, it’s the hard work they put into growing the business that allowed it to grow. Cofounder Tony Townley kept his day job running a mortgaging and loan business while running the first Zaxby location, sometimes mixing sometimes until 5 a.m.
It goes to show that while entrepreneurship can be a struggle, it can certainly pay off. 
You can read more about the world’s richest 
here
. 
Maria Gracia Santillana Linares 
Careers Reporter
Follow me on 
Forbes.com
WORK SMARTER
Practical insights and advice from Forbes staff and contributors to help you succeed in your job, accelerate your career and lead smarter.
Simply growing your network
 online won’t cut it––there is no substitute for 
in-person connections
. 
What you need to know about 
tariffs
 
if you’re in the job market. 
If you’re preparing to answer
 behavioral questions 
in your next job interview, consider 
the CARL method. 
Why you should consider a 
gig job 
in 
this labor market. 
Deep Dive
The total estimated bonus pool for Wall Street bankers reached a high not seen in nearly 40 years.
  
Photo by STAN HONDA/AFP via Getty Images
Wall Street Banker Bonuses Surge
Read Article
After a profitable year for Wall Street in 2024, its 
bankers are cashing-in on generous bonuses
. The New York State Comptroller said last week that bankers’ bonuses rose 31.5% from the previous year, contributing to a total estimated bonus pool of $47.5 billion. 
The increase in performance incentives is largely due to one of the best years in history for the stock market and dealmaking. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite each had record years in 2024, and Wall Street’s profits rose 90%. 
“Most of the time bonuses are based off of two things: What is your personal performance and what is the company’s performance,” says Nich Tremper, economist at payroll provider Gusto. “It’s discretionary compensation based on those two things.”
Add a securities employment increase––coming in at 201,500 employees, the highest annual level in at least 30 years, according to New York Comptroller Thomas DiNapoli––and you’ve got more employees earning six-figure salaries that qualified for the bonuses. Indeed, average salaries for analysts range from $160,000 to $210,000 per year after bonuses. That number can rise up to $475,000 for associates. 
But Wall Street wasn’t the only place to see bonuses increase, albeit at a much lower rate. Average end-of-year bonuses for 2024 were up 2% compared to 2023 payouts for small businesses, according to a January report from 
Gusto
, though the total share of workers who received bonuses decreased. 
Apart from Wall Street, those in the communications, technology and professional services industries saw the greatest bonus growth.
Retail, for example, saw an 8% increase in bonuses from 2023 to 2024. But one major retailer held back from them altogether, citing fiscal year performance results. Salaried employees at Target who were eligible for bonuses will only receive 87% of their potential bonus for fiscal year 2024,
 
HR Dive reported
, down from the 100% they received the previous year. 
The state of the economy has a large part to play in how much employers are distributing to their workers. “A bonus is backwards-looking,” says Tremper. “But it’s also forwards-looking. It’s a business owner deciding that they don’t need to keep that cash in the bank account and can actually invest that into their employees.” 
TOUCH BASE
 
It’s impossible to ignore the mounting criticisms of America’s most exclusive colleges. These 20 schools—10 public and 10 private—are stepping up to educate the country’s brightest students and graduating the talent employers seek.
 
Forbes
 
News from the world of work
As the Ivy Leagues continue to amass criticism from wealthy alumni, parents of students and even the federal government,
 
Forbes
 released its second iteration of the New Ivies
 list. Employers are increasingly looking at graduates from these 20 public and private universities, including newcomers Washington University in St. Louis, the University of Pittsburgh and the United States Military Academy at West Point, Emma Whitford 
reports
. 
Top vaccine official 
Peter Marks quit his position at the Federal Drug Administration (FDA)
 on Friday, criticizing Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy’s views on vaccines and his “misinformation and lies.” He’s not the first—and certainly not the last—federal employee to 
clash with his new boss.
 
Just days later, cuts at HHS 
reportedly
 began. 
Kennedy is expected to cut about a quarter of the department’s workforce,
 
about 10,000 employees
, across regional offices, the CDC, FDA, NIH, and the Centers for Medicaid and Medicare.
Job applications from federal workers are surging
, 
Indeed reports
. USDA workers and those working in DEI roles are likely hitting the job market the most, as searches for horticulture and employee relations roles increased by more than 10 times compared to this time last year. While most federal employees looking for work are still in the Washington, D.C. and Virginia area, 
Texas, California and Georgia
 are not far behind.  
Are you worried about a potential recession and how it could impact your job? 
Forbes’
 Derek Saul has been 
tracking economists’ recession warnings
 as “Liberation Day” tariffs loom. 
Here’s why it’s not time to worry yet. 
Gen X creatives are in a career meltdown
, the 
New York Times
 
reports
. Right when they should be at the peak of their career, advertising and media workers in their late 40s and 50s are trying to play catch-up in an industry now dominated by cheap, fast social media content, influencers and generative AI.
NUMBER TO NOTE
$293 million
That’s how much movies that had gender balanced cast and crew made at the worldwide box office, on average, in 2024—more than double those that didn’t, according to 
a new study.
 
 
VIDEO
How DOGE Cuts Are Impacting U.S. Businesses
Watch Video

A.
Universal Studios
B.
Disney
C.
Warner Bros.
D.
Netflix

Wise Decision Maker Guide

Greetings Monica,
Why are some states forcing government employees back to the office despite overwhelming evidence that remote work boosts productivity and saves money?
 Republican-led states like Nebraska, Ohio, Oklahoma, and Wisconsin are pushing rigid return-to-office mandates driven more by political theater than data. Ignoring federal and academic research showing the success of hybrid and remote models, these policies risk damaging public service efficiency and triggering costly turnover—just as seen under Biden’s more moderate RTO approach.

It was a presentation about really how you think, what kind of questions to ask, how to get through difficult situations.
 And the biggest thing we talk about at Vistage is decisions. After you leave this meeting, you're going to find out better ways of making decisions and the choices you make and the impact that it has on your business, your personal life, and your spiritual life."

Chet Tart
, Vistage Chair
Schedule a Free Consultation
 
What's Up With Me
It’s a puzzle to me why so many things that appear to be solely data-informed become so politicized.
 Why did WFH grow so politicized, for example? It’s not obvious at all that Republicans should favor government employees working in the office: after all, you can save a lot of money on real estate, as well as on hiring and retention costs, since people are willing to work for less and have better retention when they work remotely at least some of the time. Furthermore, productivity metrics and morale are higher when people can work remotely at least some of the time. But clearly, this issue did become politicized. Is it because of a lack of trust in public workers? Well, you can simply institute more clear accountability and tracking mechanisms, rather than forcing people back to the office, and losing all the benefits. It’s a clear example where culture wars win out over good, common business sense.
